What is Minecraft Teams?

Microsoft Teams is a business communication platform created by Microsoft. It's part of the Microsoft 365 suite of products. It provides features like chat, video calls, storing files, and connecting with other applications.

Overview

One day, I discovered that my friend was using Microsoft Teams, while I use Slack daily and had no prior knowledge of Microsoft Teams. My friend likes the software but occasionally gets frustrated while using it. This sparked my curiosity, and I decided to write a case study to explore the differences between the two platforms.

Role

Research

UX Design

Tools

Figma

Draw.io

Excel

Problems

I began researching Microsoft Teams and discovered that it is a powerful tool often utilized by large companies and those who frequently use Microsoft software. However, I encountered some issues with the software. Many people mention that some features and options are not always intuitive or easy to use. Additionally, the product lacks in notifications

Goals

Often, big companies have very strict guidelines for design principles because they are closely tied to their brand name and goals. Furthermore, altering the design entails involving multiple teams and can be costly.

In this case study, I am going to focus more on the UX than the UI aspects, as I believe that minor UX improvements can significantly enhance usability for people.

The primary goal is to identify user pain points and provide solutions for information architecture.

Research Index

  • Product Research
    • What is the company selling? Understanding the core offerings and products/services of the company.
    • Who is their target audience? Identifying the specific demographic or customer groups the company aims to reach.
    • Platform usage: Check which platforms the users mainly use for the product.
  • Detecting Users' Pain Points
    • Interview people who use the product daily.
    • Find real comments on the internet to identify crucial pain points for users.
  • Conduct a comparative analysis
    • Researching what other companies do and creating a SWOT analysis.
  • Test the product
    • Use the product and try to understand the pain points. (Currently, my company works closely with Microsoft, so I have access to their applications.)
    • Use the friend's account to test it.

Product Research

Over

1M

Microsoft Teams has become a crucial tool for remote work, and here are some statistics that highlight its usage and impact:

  • Over 1 million companies are using Microsoft Teams.
  • Microsoft Teams' video calls have increased by 1000 percent since the pandemic.
Microsoft Teams Statistics data source >>

Microsoft Teams is used the most in the Information Technology industry. 3540 Information Technology Companies are using Microsoft Teams.

Understanding User State

Check Microsoft Teams statics (Users, Trends & Data) to understand who is the mains target and how the product grow in the market. Also, need to know what is the most of user use (platform: PC, IOS, Android) to use the product.

User download count

Over 100 million Microsoft Teams Apps were downloaded on Android.

User's age
  • 60% of users are above 35 years old.
  • 72% of men and 24% of women are users of Microsoft Teams.

Detect user's pain points

In the game industry, predicting user behavior can be challenging, even after conducting numerous user playtests. Sometimes, internet user reviews play a significant role in improving the product, as they provide genuine insights from users who interact with the product daily. Whenever I launch a game, I like to read comments online to understand what aspects users find uninteresting and what bugs they encounter. I use this method to gather user feedback.

🤕

Many users have mentioned that the game is difficult to learn, some features lack intuitiveness, notifications are lacking, and there are bugs. The majority of users fall within the 35-54 age group, so I believe it's crucial to make the product more intuitive and user-friendly.

Research competitor

Microsoft Teams primarily competes with a similar service, Slack. I've also added more products to the chart to compare the target audience, goals, strengths, and unique qualities of other big companies: Slack, Google, Zoom, Discord, etc. SWOT Excel >>

Company Target Strength Weaknesses
MS Teams
  • Large size of business
  • Hub for team - work in office 365
  • Can use Microsfot product
  • Access email, calendar, documents, and other apps without leaving Teams
  • Edit files within Team
  • Syn with SharePoint or OneDrive
  • Powerful video call (250 participlants)
  • Customizable
  • Many features and options that are not always intutive or easy to use. Lack of notification
  • Slow and buggy, as it consumes many memory and band width
  • Frequent updates and changes
Slack
  • Small and medium size of business
  • Flexibility and customization
  • Use apps and bots to enhance workflow: Google drive, Trello, Zoom or Slackbot.
  • User-friendly interface
  • Robutst search funtion
  • Cost and sacalability
  • Issues with security and compliance. It does not offer end-to-end encryption or data sovereignty.
  • Messages can become unorganized quickly
Google Chat
  • Initially designed for teams and business environments.
  • It has since been made available for general consumers.
  • As a part of our Google Workspace, it helps integrate communication within the entire network of our employees with such an ease.
  • Sometimes my messages don't get delivered. It keep saying message failed,
  • Limited support for third-party integrations and bots.
Discord
  • Discord is ideal for online communities
  • Gaming companies
  • Video calls - share playscreen without lagging
  • Discord calls its integrations “bots.”

Specialized for gammers

Testing

At my current company, we work closely with Microsoft, and some parts of our work involve using Microsoft applications. So, I downloaded the web application to test it. However, my version lacked real data, so I borrowed my friend's computer to test specific aspects with real data. After collecting this information, I allocated time to thoroughly test the product and understand the pain points mentioned by users.

Solution

In this Case Study, I won't cover everything I found, so I'll focus on one scenario and provide a solution for it. I've chosen to address a frequent concern that many people have raised: notifications. I've identified areas where notifications are needed when actions are completed.

Some users also complained about excessive updates, so I brainstormed ways to make minor changes with a significant impact. I decided to re-evaluate the process of creating new team channels, as this is where teams communicate and share messages, tools, and files. Since the majority of users use Android and desktop, I conducted testing on these two platforms for the redesign.

Create new channel flow - Andriod
Problems
  • The loading screen appears randomly and disappears quickly.
  • The buttons on the 'Add Members' screen lack clarity.
  • Notifications are not functioning.
  • No alert or notification after user create new team.
Solutions
  • Ensure the loading screen stays until the transition to the next screen is complete.
  • Update the button in 'Add Members' screen.
  • Add a notification or interaction after a team is created.
  • After the user creates a team, the newest team is displayed at the top of the list, making it easier for users to find new teams (or open General Channel of newest team).
  • Provide information about the general channel while people are creating team.
Create new channel flow - Desktop
Problems
  • There are too many unnecessary steps.
  • The user interface (UI) lacks clarity.
  • There are no notifications after actions are completed.
Solutions
  • Separate the buttons for 'Join' and 'Create New.' You can do this either through a dropdown button or by creating two separate buttons
  • Provide clear UI. Ensure that users don't have to guess what it is
  • Provide clear notifications during ongoing and completed processes
  • Ensure that users don't have to guess what has happened.

Problem solved - layout

I aimed to create a simple and clean user interface, with a primary focus on ensuring the transition process is intuitive and delivering a user-friendly experience.

Add information

Add general channel information so that when users see the general channel in the team screen, they will not be confused.

Button constancy

In the next page, I will update the icons to text to make it clearer. Therefore, these icons need to be updated as well.

Bug: Loading screen

The loading screen doesn't stay long enough; it displays for only one second and disappears before transitioning to the next screen or not showing at all. It should remain visible until the next screen opens.

Update icons to make it more clear
  • X Button: Upon first seeing the 'X' icon, my initial impression was that I couldn't create a team without adding a member, and it would discard the process. However, it actually generates the page. To enhance clarity, it might be better to replace the 'X' button with a 'Back' button, which is consistent with the 'Create Team' screen. Alternatively, if the intention was to prevent users from navigating to the previous screen, it might be best to remove it.
  • Check Mark Icon: The checkmark icon is not clear; it appears as if I'm adding a friend. Since users can add as many members as they want, it would be beneficial to replace the icon with text for greater clarity. I've noticed that in the seven different chat apps I downloaded, they all use text
Notification
  • Once the channel is created, it's better to inform the user that it's done, rather than simply sending them back to the main screen. There are two ways to solve this problem:
    • Case 1: Open the general channel that the users created.
    • Case 2: Show some interaction and place the latest team at the top of the list.

Learnings

It was enjoyable to research the product that I use daily and the competitors' apps. Even though the concept is the same, the strengths vary significantly, and some are quite powerful. In the future I would like to run the user test to hear the real feedback from users.
